title: Since classes are online, professors have resorted to pre-recorded lectures, some of which are terrible in quality. I have a hard time learning by reading the textbook. What should I do? - Quora

response.answer_text: Tell the professors, with helpful feedback. I’m giving pre-recorded lectures now. It sucks. I have no real idea if students like something, or get what I just said. In a real lecture, I can judge that by expressions and questions. I would very much appreciate it if a student told me those things, and especially if they told me what things I can improve. (Yes, I did ask, several times.)

Creating good quality resources is not an easy task, and requires a different skills set from teaching from the front of a classroom. You have to work out if the quality of the resource is poor because of a lack of technical skill, or if the lecturer is just as bad in face-to-face. As we say in IT, garbage in, garbage out. Sometimes there are better resources online to learn the skills you are attempting to acquire. If there is a way to let your lecturer know how the quality of the lectures could be improved, then by all means, tell them. After all, most of them are human.

The other suggestions are good, and fortunately we live in a time when there are many avenues to learning. Being able to understand what is written is an essential skill in life. So do develop the discipline to focus rather than drifting thru a paragraph. Ask yourself at the start of each paragraph: “Why is this being written?”, and at the end of it: “What did I learn?”. Since you apparently are more adept in being able to learn interactively, and there are no tutorials or teaching assistants, try to form a study group to meet on Zoom, or Google Meet, etc., and discuss things AFTER you have understood enough to contribute. Good Luck, -bcc

Talk to the professor. Describe the problems you are facing with the videos (e.g., is the sound bad? Do you need closed captions or a transcript?) See if they are able to provide more resources. Go to consultation / office hours. If the class has teaching assistants, talk to them, too.

Underline the textbook and read aloud and write one sentence per page in the margins and try to listen the these lectures. and get through it. After this is over you will argue for better grades perhaps but for now just get through it.
Try getting a tutor or contacting your professor/teacher directly and explaining your situation.
